newsitem.title: CANADA: Canada bonds open stronger, outperform U.S. issues.
newsitem.headline: Canada bonds open stronger, outperform U.S. issues.

text.p: Canadian bonds opened stronger on Tuesday, with spreads to U.S. long bonds narrowing, driven partly by strong foreign interest to buy Canada, analysts said.

"There's a pretty good buzz towards North America from a fiscal standpoint. Given the way the Canadian dollar has weakened off and hasn't really affected the bond market I think people are seeing some value in the long end," said Michael Gregory, a fixed-income economist at Lehman Brothers.
Canada's 30-year benchmark rose C$1.01 to C$115.07 to yield 6.813 percent.
The U.S. 30-year bond rose 10/32 to yield 6.80 percent. The spread between the bonds narrowed to one basis point from six basis points at Monday's close.

Analysts said the market is now focused on whether the Canadian 30-year bond can trade to yield less than its U.S. counterpart. This would bring the entire Canadian yield curve below the U.S. yield curve for the first time ever.
"There is a big question now as to whether we can push through in the 30-year area. There seems to be some good momentum here, so we could very well see that," said Gregory.
In other prices, Canada's 10-year benchmark bond rose C$0.34 to C$106.70 to yield 6.332 percent while the U.S. 10-year rose 4/32 to 6.53 percent.
The negative spread between the bonds widened to 20 basis points from 16 basis points at Monday's close.
The three-month cash T-bill yielded 2.88 percent against its U.S. equivalent which yielded 5.0 percent.
